background_dashed.customLabel: In School-age (6-12 years old) participants, there is a small-to-moderate effect in favor of ACUP on Overall ASD symptoms. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 5 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In School-age (6-12 years old) participants, there is no difference between ACUP and controls on Sensory Profile. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 4 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In School-age (6-12 years old) participants, there is a moderate-to-strong effect in favor of ACUP on Adaptive behaviors. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 5 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In School-age (6-12 years old) participants, there is a moderate-to-strong effect in favor of ACUP on Global cognition (IQ). Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 5 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In School-age (6-12 years old) participants, there is no difference between ACUP and controls on Language (Expressive skills). Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 2 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In School-age (6-12 years old) participants, there is a small-to-moderate effect in favor of ACUP on Language (Overall skills). Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 5 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In School-age (6-12 years old) participants, there is a small-to-moderate effect in favor of ACUP on Language (Receptive skills). Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 2 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.

In School-age (6-12 years old) participants, there is a small-to-moderate effect in favor of ACUP on Mood related symptoms. Based on the analysis of the quality of the evidence produced by the 4 clinical trials exploring this effect, we have a very low confidence in the estimation of this effect.
